description: From Middle English sole, soule, from Old French sol, soul (‚Äúalone‚Äù), from Latin s≈çlus (‚Äúalone, single, solitary, lonely‚Äù). Ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sw√© (reflexive pronoun). Perhaps related to Old Latin sollus (‚Äúwhole, complete‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *solh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúsafe, healthy‚Äù). More at save.

entries.meaning: Only.
(law) Unmarried (especially of a woman); widowed.
Unique; unsurpassed.
examples: The sole brilliance of this gem.

entries.meaning: With independent power; unfettered.

description: From Middle English sole, soole, from Old English sole, solu. Reinforced by Anglo-Norman sole, Old French sole, from Vulgar Latin *sola (‚Äúbottom of the shoe‚Äù, also ‚Äúflatfish‚Äù), from Latin solea (‚Äúsandal, bottom of the shoe‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *swol- (‚Äúsole‚Äù). Cognate with Dutch zool (‚Äúsole, tread‚Äù), German Sohle (‚Äúsole, insole, bottom, floor‚Äù), Danish s√•l (‚Äúsole‚Äù), Icelandic s√≥li (‚Äúsole, outsole‚Äù), Gothic êçÉêåøêåªêåæêå∞ (sulja, ‚Äúsandal‚Äù). Related to Latin solum (‚Äúbottom, ground, soil‚Äù). More at soil.

entries.meaning: (anatomy) The bottom or plantar surface of the foot.
(footwear) The bottom of a shoe or boot.
(obsolete) The foot itself.
(zoology) Solea solea, a flatfish of the family Soleidae.

definitionGroups.group: The bottom or lower part of anything, or that on which anything rests in standing.

entries.meaning: The bottom of the body of a plough; the slade.
The bottom of a furrow.
The end section of the chanter of a set of bagpipes.
The horny substance under a horse's foot, which protects the more tender parts.
(military) The bottom of an embrasure.
(nautical) A piece of timber attached to the lower part of the rudder, to make it even with the false keel.
(nautical) The floor inside the cabin of a yacht or boat
(mining) The seat or bottom of a mine; applied to horizontal veins or lodes.

verbs.description: sole (third-person singular simple present soles, present participle soling, simple past and past participle soled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to put a sole on (a shoe or boot)

description: From Middle English sole, soole, from Old English sƒÅl (‚Äúa rope, cord, line, bond, rein, door-hinge, necklace, collar‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *sailƒÖ, *sailaz (‚Äúrope, cable‚Äù), *sail≈ç (‚Äúnoose, rein, bondage‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *sey- (‚Äúto tie to, tie together‚Äù). Cognate with Scots sale, saile (‚Äúhalter, collar‚Äù), Dutch zeel (‚Äúrope, cord, strap‚Äù), German Seil (‚Äúrope, cable, wire‚Äù), Icelandic seil (‚Äúa string, line‚Äù). Non-Germanic cognates include Albanian dell (‚Äúsinew, vein‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (dialectal or obsolete) A wooden band or yoke put around the neck of an ox or cow in the stall.

description: From Middle English sol, from Old English sol (‚Äúmire, miry place‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *sulƒÖ (‚Äúmire, wallow, mud‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *s≈´l- (‚Äúthick liquid‚Äù). Cognate with Saterland Frisian soal (‚Äúditch‚Äù), Dutch sol (‚Äúwater and mud filled pit‚Äù), German Suhle (‚Äúmire, wallow‚Äù), Norwegian saula, s√∏yla (‚Äúmud puddle‚Äù). More at soil.

entries.meaning: (dialectal, Northern England) A pond or pool; a dirty pond of standing water.

description: From earlier sowle (‚Äúto pull by the ear‚Äù). Origin unknown. Perhaps from sow (‚Äúfemale pig‚Äù) +‚Äé -le, as in the phrase "take a sow by the wrong ear", or from Middle English sole (‚Äúrope‚Äù). See above.

verbs.description: sole (third-person singular simple present soles, present participle soling, simple past and past participle soled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal) To pull by the ears; to pull about; haul; lug.
